sentence: Few operators have historically been as skilled as Chesapeake in quickly assembling large acreage blocks within emerging plays.

Most recently, the company announced plans to exchange nonoperated interests in Wyoming's Powder River Basin with RKI Exploration and Production, which increased its net acreage position and working interest in the play from three hundred twenty two thousand to three hundred eighty eight thousand and thirty eight percent to seventy nine percent, respectively.
The firm's historical tendency to pay top dollar and offer more favorable royalty rates to landowners, however, generally leads to higher break even points for its sizable resource inventory.

In addition, several of Chesapeake's plays in particular its acreage in the Anadarko Basin and the Rocky Mountain region are still early in their life cycles, with a good amount of uncertainty surrounding their ultimate economic profiles.

And while we believe Chesapeake's close to nine million net acres represent significant monetization potential, we don't believe the firm will be able to generate returns on capital above its cost of capital until much later in our ten year forecast window, thanks in part to the overhang of legacy midstream obligations in the Haynesville and Barnett regions and meaningful undeveloped acreage investments that contribute nothing to Chesapeake's current production profile.

In the near term, we expect Chesapeake's returns on invested capital to come under heavy pressure as the firm works to optimize drilling and completion costs and as lower commodity prices and the overhang of legacy midstream obligations pressure margins.

Longer term, we think Chesapeake can achieve returns near its cost of capital as oil and gas prices recover and as legacy obligations roll off, although this likely won't occur until the end of our ten year forecast period.

Valuation one/twenty two/two thousand sixteen After incorporating the most recent leg down in oil and natural gas futures prices and dialing back our assumptions regarding drilling and completion activity over the next several years, we are reducing our fair value estimate by dollar one, from dollar thirteen per share to dollar twelve per share.

Our revised fair value estimate implies forward two thousand sixteen and two thousand seventeen enterprise value/EBITDAX multiples of seventy four times and twenty six times, respectively, and is based on our ten year discounted cash flow model and an assessment of trading multiples, comparable transactions, and longer term resource potential.
We project average daily net production of four.one billion cubic feet equivalent in two thousand fifteen, three.seven

The firm's push to achieve held by production status in certain plays, along with minimum takeaway commitments, should continue to drive drilling activity over the next few years, albeit at a greatly reduced pace relative to historical levels.

As a result of declining production growth and continued low oil and natural gas prices, we forecast adjusted EBITDA of dollar two.two billion in two thousand fifteen, dollar seven hundred fifty seven million in two thousand sixteen, and dollar eight hundred fourteen million in two thousand seventeen.

Risk one/twenty four/two thousand sixteen Chesapeake's biggest risk is a substantial and prolonged drop in oil and gas prices, which would depress profits, slow development plans, reduce the value of its properties, and potentially lead to a credit event.

Other risks include a disruption in the asset market, which would limit the company's ability to monetize its acreage holdings; execution risk in Chesapeake's emerging plays ; potential midstream bottlenecks, especially in the Utica and Marcellus; and regulatory headwinds that could ultimately eat into profitability.

Management one/twenty two/two thousand sixteen Until his departure in April two thousand thirteen, Chesapeake was led by CEO Aubrey McClendon, one of the most visible and controversial personalities in U.S. E and P. McClendon was effectively forced out following a series of questionable personal and professional decisions that culminated in a boardroom coup in the spring of two thousand twelve.
Taking over as CEO in June two thousand thirteen was Doug Lawler, who also became a member of the board of directors.
Lawler most recently headed Anadarko's international and deep water operations, where, among other things, he led the company's multitrain LNG development project in Mozambique.
He previously headed Anadarko's onshore unconventional development efforts, which encompassed the Eagle Ford, Marcellus, Haynesville, and Permian areas.
We believe Lawler's appointment was a step in the right direction for Chesapeake.
had an impressive climb through the ranks of a highly regarded firm in Anadarko, with roles ranging from asset development to operations to strategic planning.

Moreover, he appears entirely comfortable dealing with the financial, legal, and operational complexity that he inherited at Chesapeake, as evidenced by his successful oversight of Anadarko's offshore Mozambique assets.
Under Lawler, Chesapeake has proved to be a standard steward of shareholder capital.

Lawler has moved aggressively to cut expenses, improve the company's capital allocation, and simplify the complex balance sheet, all in an effort to transform Chesapeake into a low cost, growth oriented, return focused exploration and production firm, rather than the bloated land machine it had become under McClendon.
Chesapeake's directors and executive officers collectively hold approximately one percent of common shares outstanding.

Executive compensation appears reasonable and in line with peers and comprises base pay, bonuses, and long term performance linked incentives including stock options and performance share and restricted stock units.

Overview Profile: Chesapeake Energy, based in Oklahoma City, explores for, produces, and markets natural gas, oil, and natural gas liquids in the U.S. It focuses on unconventional plays, with large positions in the Barnett, Eagle Ford, Haynesville, and Marcellus shales, as well as leasehold in a number of liquids rich basins.
Chesapeake controls close to nine million net acres across its properties.
At year end two thousand fourteen, the firm's proved reserves totaled fourteen.six

Analyst Note // Check Point Software announced firstquarter fiscal results that were largely in line with our expectations.

The highlights for the quarter include a hardware refresh of firewall appliances, release of R software, and the announcement of SandBlast Agentï¿½_Check Point's effort to capture revenues from a nascent market of endpoint detection and remediation products.
Despite last year's growth in its salesforce, we have yet to see a material improvement in topline results.
Our thesis and fair value estimate of dollar per share remains unchanged for this narrowmoat stock, and we view shares as fully valued today.
Check Point continues to grow its revenues slower than the overall market expansion of percent .
Gross margin remained largely unchanged year over year and grew basis points sequentially to .
We expect a slow uptick on gross margin to continue as revenue mix shifts away from product and licenses toward more profitable software subscriptions.
Operating margin declined basis points year over year and basis points sequentially to percent due to higher investments in sales marketing and research and development activities.
All in, operating income and EPS were dollar million and dollar .

Investment Thesis // The network security market has been changing rapidly in the past several years, and Check Point, an industry leader, has adapted by expanding its product portfolio to cater to the growing needs for cybersecurity.

With more computing loads moving to the cloud, we think Check Point's expertise in building software firewalls will have an advantage over its rivals that rely on custom silicon to deliver highperformance solutions.

Israelibased Check Point is a leading provider of networking security equipment, selling network firewalls, intrusion prevention, and other defense technologies designed to detect, stop, and remedy a growing amount of cybersecurity threats.
Corporations consider these products necessary to protect private and confidential information stored within their networks.
Check Point is positioned as a leading vendor, with a large customer base in the midsize to large enterprise segment.
Since its inception, Check Point's strength has been in network firewall equipment, which we view as one of the earliest and essential parts of network defense against cyber attackers.
Check Point has been at the forefront of firewall development with its famous Firewall product release in .
Analyst Note // China Mobile's firstquarter fiscal showed strong underlying growth, with services revenue up .
As usual, no other financial details were provided with this quarterly result, but we suspect losses from Tower Company may have something to do with the lower net profit growth.

We believe this strong underlying growth has been masked in recent years by oneoffs, such as the imposition of valueadded tax, or VAT, in mid and the data carryforward implemented at the beginning of fourthquarter .
We retain our narrow moat rating and increase our fair value estimate to HKD per share from HKD per share .
We also retain our Poor stewardship rating, based primarily on the company's poor track record for capital management.
We forecast percent percent per year earnings growth for China Mobile over the next five years on an underlying basis.
We believe this will be driven by continued conversion of nondatacapable G customers to G and G phones.
Momentum is strong for this catalyst: the percentage of China Mobile's customers on G/G phones has risen to percent as at the end of March, from percent a year ago.
The ability to claim higher VAT reductions on input costs should also help boost earnings.

We estimate that China Mobile's earnings were hit by about percent in mid with the introduction of the VAT, but as VAT is introduced in more sectors, China Mobile's earnings should recover, as it will be able to claim VAT deductions on more input costs.

The government has announced that VAT will be introduced to some large sectors in real estate, finance, insurance, and consumer services from May, so we could see a small boost to China Mobile's secondhalf earnings.
Investment Thesis // With more than million customers, China Mobile not only dwarfs its Chinese competitors, but is also the world's largest wireless telephone company by far.
It has more G/G subscribers than its competitors despite being handicapped by the Chinese government, which required it to use the home grown TDSCDMA technology standard for G mobile.

However, with the industry shift to G, the technology playing field is more level, as the strong handset ecosystem development in the first year of operation of China Mobile's TD LTE network means that the technology gap between its G version and its competitors is much smaller than it was for G.
In addition, China Mobile has had about a month head start on its G network rollout, with . million G base stations by yearend and . million planned by .
This gives it a strong head start against its competitors, who only gained national FDD LTE licences in February.

Investment Thesis ten/twenty eight/two thousand fifteen C.H. Robinson dominates the dollar fifty billion U.S. highway brokerage market, and we think its immense network of shippers and carriers supports a wide economic moat.

Although Robinson is by no means immune to cyclical downturns, its variable cost model helps shield profitability during periods of anemic freight demand, as evidenced by a long history of above average profitability.

The firm does not own transportation equipment, and nearly seventy five percent of operating expenses are tied to performance based variable compensation, which tends to move with net revenue growth over the long run.
We think the firm remains well positioned to capitalize on domestic third party logistics consolidation despite gradually rising competition.
Over and above underlying freight demand, market share gains are likely to remain the key growth driver for Robinson over the long run.

For perspective, we estimate Robinson's stake of the domestic fright brokerage industry increased to twenty one percent twenty two percent in two thousand fourteen from about thirteen percent in two thousand four, based on market statistics from Armstrong and Associates.

The highway brokerage business is still highly fragmented, and smaller, less sophisticated providers are finding it increasingly difficult to keep up with rising demand for truckload capacity and informational know how.

Robinson's industry leading network of asset based truckers is becoming even more valuable to shippers given constraints on truckload supply, which stems from the driver shortage and regulatory headwinds.
While spot activity dissipated during the second half of two thousand fifteen, we think shippers' concerns over capacity will keep Robinson's contractual business opportunities healthy.
Robinson is also positioning its international air and ocean forwarding operations to contribute to growth.
In late two thousand twelve, it purchased top shelf Phoenix International, which more than doubled Robinson's scale in this business.
We think the firm can post high single digit net revenue expansion in this segment over the long run, as its newfound scale supports market share gains.
Additionally, the firm's first quarter two thousand fifteen acquisition of Freightquote further expands its reach into the growing less than truckload brokerage niche.
Economic Moat ten/twenty eight/two thousand fifteen C.H. Robinson maintains a wide economic moat thanks to the network effect.
Its industry leading network of shippers and carriers reinforces its compelling value proposition and duplication by small providers with fewer resources would be a formidable task.
In its core transportation businesses, C.H. Robinson's substantial customer base of more than forty thousand shippers affords significant buying power.
As a result, the company can procure capacity at lower rates than shippers could generally obtain directly with carriers, thereby providing customers with opportunities for material cost savings.
Furthermore, C.H. Robinson's vast network of fifty six thousand asset based carriers across most transportation modes acts as a valuable source of capacity for shippers.
We believe this attribute is becoming more appreciated by customers given the strong potential for intermittent truckload capacity shortages in the years ahead.
Tight capacity conditions are linked to the driver shortage and rising regulation, including the government's CSA program and recently revised hours of service rules.
These factors are keeping most truckers from materially increasing fleet size despite decent freight demand.

Additionally, C.H. Robinson's relationships with air, ocean, and rail carriers support multimodal capabilities that optimize shippers' use of truckload, less than truckload, and rail intermodal on the domestic front and air and ocean freight for overseas shipping.
We believe demand for multimodal solutions is rising, driven in part by improving service levels from the rails and shippers' focus on supply chain efficiency.
This dynamic should play well into the hands of threePL providers such as Robinson because asset based truckers must focus on maximizing tractor utilization.
From the perspective of carriers, C.H. Robinson is a highly attractive source of freight opportunities, given its ability to aggregate fragmented demand across a broad customer base of shippers.
In this way, truckers can minimize empty miles and supplement sales efforts.
While competitors with sufficient capital can replicate technology, C.H. Robinson's robust proprietary IT platforms provide differentiation from smaller providers with fewer resources.

We expect the company to garner additional market share from less capable threePL competitors as supply chains continue to increase in complexity, requiring sophisticated informational expertise and broad, vetted capacity relationships.
C.H. Robinson's strong technology infrastructure, coupled with a vast reservoir of market data, also enhances internal pricing decisions and improves customer connectivity and reporting.

Moreover, its systems can raise switching costs, particularly in cases where it integrates with customers' IT syste Miss Valuation two/sixteen/two thousand sixteen During the first quarter of two thousand fifteen, C.H. Robinson acquired privately held truck broker Freightquote for dollar three hundred sixty five million in cash.
Freightquote specializes in less than truckload brokerage and added about six percent to Robinson's net revenue run rate.
Overall, we think the deal will prove modestly accretive to shareholder value over time.
For two thousand sixteen, we expect total net revenue growth of four percent five percent .

Behind this, we anticipate two percent three percent organic truckload volume gains and gross margin expansion linked to the impact of lower fuel costs paid by third party carriers and the time lag in passing along lower carrier rates to shippers.
Buy rates for truckload capacity fell during the second half of two thousand fifteen due to more moderate industry shipment demand and more balanced supply and demand relative to last year.

Assuming U.S. macroeconomic trends remain positive, we expect operating conditions to remain favorable for intermediaries as truckload capacity constraints will remain a factor on certain lanes thanks to the driver shortage and regulatory changes .

operating margins to remain roughly flat in two thousand sixteen, as higher Freightquote related amortization costs and continued investment in the salesforce and IT infrastructure offset underlying productivity gains.
Looking further out, we think the company can expand organic net revenue by five percent on average as it takes share from asset based truckers and small brokers.
The industry remains highly fragmented and the network effect bestows powerful advantages in the asset light brokerage space, particularly in periods of limited truck capacity.
We project consolidated operating margin to reach roughly thirty eight.five
This is slightly below the firm's five year average adjusted margin of thirty nine percent because of the addition of Phoenix and Freightquote, which operate at lower margins.

Risk ten/twenty eight/two thousand fifteen Although C.H. Robinson's variable cost business model provides a partial of buffer for profitability, the company is not immune to cyclical downturns in freight demand when economic conditions deteriorate, gross revenue trends will reflect softer shipment volume from customers.
During periods of accelerating freight demand, truckload capacity typically firms and carrier rates rise.
Historically, this dynamic has driven gross profit margin compression because the company passes through higher carrier rates to customers on a time lag.

Along these lines, Robinson's migration to large, price committed customers over the past three plus years is a double edge sword these shippers provide a greater degree of sticky, scheduled freight, but they also boost gross margin risk.

Broader trucking industry issues such as driver availability and intensifying safety regulation will probably drive intermittent capacity shortages on key lanes in the years ahead, even with modest freight demand growth.
While the firm's value proposition tends to strengthen in such an environment because of its capacity access, gross margins can get squeezed in the short run as carrier rates spike.
This is because the firm usually encounters roughly a six month lag in passing along cost of hire increases to customers.
In Robinson's core truckload brokerage operations, fuel costs are largely a pass through to shippers.
That said, declining fuel prices can artificially boost the firm's gross profit margin percentage because lower fuel surcharges will reduce gross revenue with little impact on net revenue.

Management ten/twenty eight/two thousand fifteen We think C.H. Robinson's senior management team has done an admirable job managing the firm's nonasset based model a history of positive cash flow from operations, industry leading profitability, and robust returns on invested capital is evidence of above average execution.
CEO John Wiehoff has been at the helm since two thousand two and with the firm since one thousand nine hundred ninety two.
Management believes its entrepreneurial culture and decentralized structure have driven its success and growth over the years.
Employees are compensated based on the profitability of their local office, and the company sustains its culture by promoting from within its ranks.
Robinson pays a quarterly dividend, which has increased annually over the past decade, and has a long history of share repurchases.
Robinson has not historically been acquisitive, but its strategy has been shifting.
In two thousand twelve, it acquired top shelf global air and ocean forwarder Phoenix International, which has thus far proved beneficial in terms of boosting Robinson's scale in that market.
In early two thousand fifteen, it acquired less than truckload brokerage specialist Freightquote, and we expect the transaction to prove quite favorable over time.

Freightquote expanded Robinson's base of small shippers, which have been turning to intermediaries for help securing trucks given concerns over the impact of the driver shortage and regulatory changes on truckload capacity.

Additionally, Freightquote broadened Robinson's LTL carrier network and boosted its LTL business by about thirty percent brokered LTL freight is on the rise, in part because carriers are looking to supplement revenue sources.
In June two thousand fifteen, Andrew Clarke succeeded Chad Lindbloom as CFO.
Clarke has significant leadership experience in the transportation industry, having served as CEO of Panther Expedited, which was acquired by LTL trucker ArcBest in two thousand thirteen.
Before that, he spent five years as CFO of top shelf airport to airport shipping specialist Forward Air.
He has long been an integral part of the firm's strategic initiatives, including those on the IT front.
Thus, we suspect the firm is looking to leverage his leadership experience to spearhead key IT efforts, including the rollout of its Navisphere platform.
Overview Profile: C.H. Robinson is a top tier non asset based third party logistics provider with a significant focus on domestic truck brokerage .
It also operates a growing air and ocean forwarding business and a legacy produce sourcing operation .
The remainder of net revenue reflects rail intermodal and fees from outsourced transportation management services.

Analyst Note // Following the profit warning issued ahead of China Unicom's firstquarter result, the company has released the details of the result.
As outlined in the warning, the company added . million mobile billing customers during the quarter, and overall service revenue of CNY .
However, costs associated with adding customers drove bottomline profit down to CNY million, which was the reason for the profit warning.
We were pleasantly surprised by the bounce back in sequential quarterly EBITDA to CNY billion, up from CNY .
per share from HKD per share, given the positive impact of the newly added subscribers on our mediumterm revenue forecasts.
Our U.S.dollardenominated ADR fair value estimate is unchanged, as a result of our rounding policy.

Our narrow moat rating on China Unicom, based on cost advantages, is retained, as is our negative moat trend, which is based on the company's declining technology advantage as the market moves to G mobile.
One positive element of China Mobile's quarterly result is the progress it has made in adding fixedline broadband customers.
China Mobile added . million fixed broadband customers during the first quarter, to end with . million fixedline customers.
China Unicom added . million fixed broadband customers, to end the quarter with .

Although China Mobile's customers generate only around one third of the average revenue per user of China Unicom's customers, we are surprised by how aggressively China Mobile is attacking this market.
Investment Thesis // China Unicom is one of two main fixedline telephone companies in China, each with its own traditional territory, which generates its moat.
It is also the secondlargest wireless operator in the country, which up until the first half of was generating the majority of its growth.
However, much better growth is being generated by the fixedline business, which saw percent revenue growth in, compared with percent revenue decline from mobiles.
We did see signs of turnaround for the mobile business in firstquarter with stronger customer and service revenue growth.

We think management is doing a better job of marketing bundles of fixedline telephony and broadband services, which has stabilised the fixedline subscriber base and invigorated the broadband business.
Additionally, the firm is offering its fixedline services bundled with mobile.

Analyst Note // Core Labs reported firstquarter results that were slightly below our expectations as well as management's prior guidance as industry conditions deteriorated further during the quarter.

Management is guiding toward a slightly weaker second quarter before revenue and operating income rebounds in the second half of the year, implying a bottoming during the second quarter before an anticipated sharp recovery in price levels and activity later in the year and into .
While we generally agree with management's timing, we think the recovery will be slower and more extended than its V shaped recovery comments would suggest.
That said, we continue to view Core Labs as one of the more compelling investment opportunities in the industry.

Although we remain cautious of the service sector as a whole given the likelihood of less required investment to achieve greater production, we think those firms that can contribute to cost control, improve recoveries and increase return on investment stand to succeed.
Our fair value estimate remains unchanged after updating our model with firstquarter results and secondquarter guidance that is not as poor as we were expecting.

Shares are trading slightly above our fair value estimate, but given its quality and valuation relative to other service firms we continue to view Core Lab as a Best Idea and we recommend keeping an eye on it as volatility is likely to present future buying opportunities.
Investment Thesis // By focusing on differentiated, valueenhancing products and services that are difficult to replicate, Core Laboratories delivers industryleading margins and returns on capital.
Its value proposition is simple: Offer services that help oil companies better understand their reservoirs, ultimately leading to greater production.
Over time, we expect Core to increase its market share, thus leveraging its fixedcost base and driving margin expansion.
But while it's better positioned than peers for the current downturn, it's not completely immune and will see earnings suffer as a result.
Most affected will be the production enhancement segment, which played a large part in Core's revenue growth and margin expansion in recent years.
The segment's success largely resulted from the increase in unconventional drilling.
As a result, it is likely to experience a greater downturn in the next two years than in the previous cycle, given the magnitude of capitalexpenditure cuts targeted at unconventional drilling.
However, we expect an eventual recovery will result in increased adoption of Core's integrated services as evaluating and improving the effectiveness of well completions becomes more critical.
Also, the trend toward more horizontal wells with more fracking stages will benefit Core by increasing opportunities for its services.

Analyst Note // Although we don't think Cloud Peak Energy is in danger of bankruptcy, the Chapter filings of peers Alpha Natural Resources, Arch Coal, and Peabody Energy have shrunk the number of potential coal companies we can cover.
With the limited benefit of continuing coverage of the domestic coal industry with so few public equities, we are dropping analyst coverage of Cloud Peak.
We provide broad coverage of more than, companies across more than industry groups and adjust our coverage as necessary based on client demand and investor interest.
Investment Thesis // Cloud Peak Energy is one of the lowestcost players in the lowestcost coal mining region in the world: the Powder River Basin in southeast Montana and northeast Wyoming.
While PRB coal is very cheap, its use ultimately depends on natural gas prices.
When natural gas prices fall in the low dollar per thousand cubic feet range, significant coaltogas switching occurs.
While we expect coal's competitiveness to improve as natural gas prices reach our midcycle forecast of dollar /mcf, Cloud Peak will face significant challenges until then.
Cloud Peak operates three surface coal mines in the PRB, with production capacity of roughly million tons annually.

From a cost perspective, the PRB is one of the world's most advantageous coal mining regions, as its thick, uniform coal beds allow miners to use massive trucks and draglines for easy and efficient access and transport.

While shipping costs for PRB coal can be more than times extraction costs on a perton basis, the majority of the U.S. coal power plants still find it more economical to burn PRB coal than other types of coal, given PRB coal's abundance, minimal sulfur content, and ultralow production costs.

Furthermore, while Central Appalachian coal miners' costs continue to balloon as a result of geology, regulation, and safety issues, threatening the longterm viability of CAPP coal use, PRB coal costs are expected to grow at a much more moderate pace.
Cloud Peak's keen focus on cost control has helped it manage challenging coal markets.
However, the company can't cut costs to fully compensate for the weakness in coal prices.
Cloud Peak will need a significant improvement in natural gas prices in order to return to meaningful profitability.
Economic Moat // We believe Cloud Peak enjoys a narrow economic moat primarily because of its large, established position in the lowcost Powder River Basin in the United States.
We're big fans of the company's PRB operations, where Cloud Peak is the thirdlargest of four miners that control the basin, including

Clorox is poised to use recent profit gains to support the intangible asset source of its wide moat.
Price four million seventy two thousand sixteen Fair Value Estimate Uncertainty

Investment Thesis twelve/fifteen/two thousand fifteen Although Clorox plays in several categories where private label maintains significant penetration, we think its focus on winning with consumers has enabled the firm to post profitable sales growth.

For one, we've long believed that Clorox's brand equity and investments in product innovation and marketing support are a plusin aggregate representing about dollar six hundred million of spending annually, or eleven percent of consolidated sales.
Overall, Clorox targets generating three points of incremental sales growth from innovation annually, in line with its historical average.

From our vantage point, operating with a portfolio of leading brands that span the grocery store positions Clorox as a valued partner for retailers that are reluctant to risk costly outof stocks with unproven suppliers.
In the aggregate, this entrenches the firm's products in retailers' supply chains and supports the firm's intangible asset moat
Analyst Note Sales and Profit Gains Persist for Clorox in the Second Quarter Shares a Bit Above Our Valuation by Erin Lash, two/four/two thousand sixteen
Bulls Say Ô After facing many years of price controls, Clorox exited the volatile Venezuelan market in September two thousand fourteen, which we think will prop up sales and profits.
Ô Premium innovations are gaining ground at the expense of baseline offerings, indicating to us that consumers are still willing to pay up where they see added value.
Ô The firm is extending its reach in the organic space by expanding Burt's Bees into face and body offerings and is supporting these new products with TV advertisinga first for the brand.

Further, Clorox competes in the household and personalcare markets against significantly larger rivals, but its focus on niche categories has served it well, and its lean cost structure has resulted in operating margins in the high teens, comparable with leading industry peers like Procter and Gamble.

Beyond maintaining a tight focus on its cost structure, we think Clorox's efforts to expand into adjacent product categorieswith the aim of reducing its dependence on product lines like food containers, where consumers are probably more inclined to shop on priceare paying off and helping it stand out from the competition.
From our perspective, this type of expansion can smartly leverage a strong brand like Clorox or Glad while also boosting margins.
We continue to believe that robust cash generation positions Clorox well to withstand competitive headwinds and affords the firepower to reinvest in its brands and enhance shareholder returns.
Beyond expanding organically, we also think bolton acquisitions could be in the cards, although we expect the firm to continue to show prudence in its pursuit of potential targets.
Bears Say Ô Though oil prices have declined, the firm is still battling increased transportation costs, restricting the potential for further profit gains.
Ô Promotions are expected to remain elevated, but management has stressed that this reflects the competitive landscape and efforts to drive trials, rather than retailer pushback.

Ô Clorox plays in several categories with pronounced privatelabel penetrationlike bleach, charcoal, and trash bagsand its volume could be negatively affected if consumers trade down to lowerpriced alternatives.
More... TTM Sales dollar mil five thousand six hundred ninety three

Economic Moat twelve/fifteen/two thousand fifteen We assign Clorox a wide economic moat because we think the household and personalcare company will generate excess economic profits for at least the next twenty years.

with leading brands, solid relationships with retailers, and a relative cost advantage, which in the aggregate allows the firm to sustain leading market share and generate solid returns and excess cash flow for shareholders.
More than eighty percent of Clorox's portfolio hold the numberone or two spot in the aisle.

The brand equity inherent in its product lineup is further evidenced by the fact that since two thousand five, the firm has taken sixty six price increases across its business, and sixty four of those are still in placea ninety seven percent success rate.

Even when the firm isn't actively increasing prices to offset higher commodity costs, new products tend to come with a higher price tag, and in general, volume has not come under pressure for an extended period.
By operating as a leading consumer packaged goods manufacturer, Clorox is a valued partner for retailers, supporting its intangible asset moat source.
The resources Clorox maintains to bring new products to market and market those offerings in front of consumers to drive customer traffic also enhances the stickiness of its retailer relationships.

Further, while we acknowledge that switching costs for consumers among products in the household and personalcare space are extremely low, we think trusted manufacturers like Clorox that supply products across multiple categories such as cleaning products, fabric care, cat litter, and food storage have deeply entrenched their position in the eyes of retailers, which are reluctant to risk costly outofstocks with unproven suppliers.
Clorox has also amassed scale and subsequently is able to garner a lower cost per unit than its smaller peers.
In fact, Clorox's margins are not out of whack compared with those of significantly larger peer Procter and Gamble .

Clorox has worked to enhance the efficiency of its sourcing effortsit coowns mines to obtain specific clay for its cat litter products and garners the main raw material for charcoal from mills located close to its manufacturing facilities.
In addition, Clorox isn't just bringing new products to market that cost more to manufacture, as several new products are valueadded but also come with reduced cost.

These factors, combined with the fact that Clorox boasts returns on invested capital far in excess of our seven percent cost of capital estimate, support our stance that the firm maintains a wide economic moat.

Valuation two/five/two thousand sixteen Our fair value estimate stands at dollar one hundred fourteen per share, which implies fiscal two thousand seventeen price/earnings of twenty two times, enterprise value/EBITDA of thirteen times, and a free cash flow yield of four percent .
Our longterm forecast still calls for four percent annual topline growth and operating margins amounting to more than nineteen percent in fiscal two thousand twenty five.

Despite competing in categories with high levels of privatelabel penetration, Clorox ensures its intangible asset remains a source of competitive edge by investing behind its brands to yield market share gains, which boosts its pricing power longer term.

However, the combination of soft consumer spending and increased promotions tempers our nearterm sales forecast, although foreign currency headwinds are not likely to be as pronounced relative to its peers, given its significant concentration in the United States.
We forecast topline growth just south of one percent in fiscal two thousand sixteen and nearly three percent in fiscal two thousand seventeen.
Longer term, we anticipate around sixty percent of the firm's topline growth will be driven by higher volume, with the remainder resulting from increased prices and favorable mix.
Input cost inflation has made margin expansion difficult to come by over the past few years, but a modest tailwind from lower commodity costs should aid profits over the next few quarters.
However, we suspect that logistics costs are likely to remain elevated.
From our vantage point, the firm's costmanagement efforts should also lead to modest profit improvement during our forecast period.
While we think that a portion of any savings generated will be reinvested in the business in the form of

advertising spending and product innovation, we forecast operating margins will expand to nineteen percent by fiscal two thousand twenty five, about one hundred eighty basis points above the average margin generated over the past five years.

Throughout the next five years, we expect return on invested capital to average thirty two percent, well in excess of our seven percent cost of capital estimate, supporting our opinion that Clorox maintains a wide economic moat.
We place a low degree of uncertainty around our fair value estimate for the shares, as we think projections of the company's cash flows fall within a fairly narrow range.
Risk twelve/fifteen/two thousand fifteen The commoditydriven nature of its business can affect Clorox's profitability.
Further, adverse weather has challenged the firm's sales from time to time.
Privatelabel penetration is significant in many of the company's categories, and heightened competitive pressures persist.
Clorox has stepped up its merchandising efforts and is investing behind its brands, which we view as an appropriate response.
Fortyfive percent of total revenue is concentrated with only five retailers, indicating that Clorox maintains significant exposure to retailer consolidation, which could weaken its pricing power.
Adding to the firm's risk profile is that Clorox derives about four percent of annual sales from the volatile market of Argentina.

Unlike Venezuela, which Clorox exited in September two thousand fourteen following multiple years of not being able to take pricing to offset cost pressures, management appears committed to competing in Argentina given the continued profits it enjoys.

While Clorox has looked to several strategic acquisitions to build out its product and geographic footprint, the timing of the Burt's Bees deal was poor at two thousand eight prices, management had to write down dollar two hundred fifty eight million in goodwill in two thousand eleven when the optimistic projections underpinning the purchase price failed to materialize.
However, we don't disagree with the aim of product diversification or the focus on the natural or organic niche.

The issue is more about growth as Clorox has come to realize with its Green Works brand, consumers are willing to pay for natural or organic products, but not necessarily the premium that was once expected.
Management twelve/fifteen/two thousand fifteen We view Clorox's stewardship of shareholder capital as Exemplary.

Solid underlying fundamentals, strong cash flow generation, and a commitment to returning excess cash to shareholders all point to management running Clorox for the long term and not the quarter, which is a plus, from our perspective.
Management has shed noncore assets, including its Armor All brand, and has made acquisitions to diversify its product base.

Enhancing shareholder returns is not an area to which Clorox merely pays lip service, as the company has returned more than one hundred twenty percent of available free cash flow to shareholders over the past ten years, doubling the dividend payment in just the past six years.
Returns on invested capital have been more than two times our cost of capital estimate in each of the past ten years, supporting our take.

Donald Knauss stepped down as CEO in November two thousand fourteen and handed the reins to Benno Dorer, formerly Clorox's executive vice president and chief operating officer of cleaning, international, and corporate strategy.

Dorer joined Clorox ten years ago after spending fifteen years at Procter and Gamble, indicating that he has significant knowledge and experience not only at Clorox but also in the global household and personalcare industry.
We don't anticipate the leadership change will ultimately prompt a material shift in the firm's stewardship or strategic direction.
George Harad, formerly the executive chairman of OfficeMax, serves as the firm's independent chairman.
We like that different individuals hold the positions of CEO and chairman.
Compensation at Clorox is reasonable, with seventy two percent eighty six percent of executive managers' annual pay based on performance.

for senior management, which amount to six times base salary for the CEO and three times base salary for other executive officers, as this tends to align management's interests with those of shareholders.
Overview Profile: For one hundred years, Clorox has operated in the household product industry, expanding its portfolio to include such leading brands as Clorox, Glad, Hidden Valley, and Kingsford.
The firm distributes its products through mass merchants, grocery stores, and other retail outlets.
With its acquisition of Burt's Bees in two thousand seven, Clorox gained entry into the fastgrowing natural personalcare category.
International sales amount to just less than twenty percent of the firm's consolidated total, with about two thirds resulting from fastergrowing emerging markets.

This has been a multiyear project that included moving the headquarters to Dallas from Michigan in .
Additionally, in, it acquired Sterling Bancshares, in Texas, which increased Comerica's number of locations in the state by percent .
While Comerica remains tied to the Michigan market, the bank will continue to deemphasize its reliance on its former home state.
This strategy is intended to help Comerica improve upon and distance itself from its poor profitability as returns on equity have remained below double digits since .

To illustrate the transformation, we can look to its Michigan loan portfolio, which has decreased since from more than dollar billion, when it represented percent of the portfolio, down to dollar billion, or percent of the total portfolio, at the end of .
Meanwhile, California has become the bank's largest market, with loans totaling dollar billion at the end of, representing percent of total loans.
Nearer term, Comerica's presence in Texas and its exposure to energy will present challenges.

While we generally believe that Comerica is a good loan underwriter, macroeconomic conditions in energy producing areas will continue to weigh on the bank's credit quality.

Nevertheless, we generally like Comerica's longer term prospects given its ample supply of cheap deposit funding while it creates deep advisorstyle relationships with its small and midsize business clients.
We think that if Comerica can limit credit losses and keep a lid on operating costs, this bank can again produce excess returns for shareholders.
Economic Moat // We think that Comerica has a narrow moat.
This commercial lender benefits from sticky client relationships that have been developed over many years.

Banks like Comerica can provide numerous deposit and transactional services for clients, as well as helping to secure loans, and as businesses utilize more and more services with one bank, it becomes less likely that a client will change its banking relationship and where it keeps its deposits.
As a result, Comerica's clients face high switching costs because they become so integrated with their bank.
It has longtenured business relationships in Michigan, Texas, and California, where it possesses a large share of the market for deposit funding.

Economic Moat nine/twenty one/two thousand fifteen We believe that the economic moats of financial exchanges stem primarily from network effects, intangible assets, and cost advantages.
As more buyers and sellers use a financial exchange, bidask spreads tighten and the order book deepens.
The benefit from a lower market impact cost of using a highvolume exchange is often greater than any savings from using another exchange with a lower explicit transaction cost.
CME : CME Group Inc Class A Analyst Report | Analyst Report
Leading equity exchanges have a storied brand that attracts company listings, while derivative exchanges often have exclusive products based on their selfdeveloped or licensed intellectual property.
The vertically integrated clearing model is also a key factor of many of the widemoat exchanges, as clients must open and close their positions at the same exchange.
The relatively high initial capital investment and fixedcostbase nature of exchanges imparts a cost advantage over new exchanges.

It is the primary venue for the trading of certain futures contracts, such as those related to U.S. dollar interest rates, U.S. crude oil, and corn, which gives it the networkeffectrelated benefit of the lowest market impact cost.
For example, the minimum tick size for most Eurodollar futures contracts is dollar twelve.fifty per contract compared with the average transaction fee per contract of around dollar .fifty.

So, even if another exchange were to charge less than dollar .fifty per contract, a onetick size worse execution on even a fraction of contracts would wipe out any savings to the customer from a lower transaction fee.
This advantage was recently demonstrated by NYSE Liffe U.S. and ELX failing to gain material traction in the U.S. interestrate futures market despite having contracts similar to CME.
The company also possesses exclusive licenses to products, such as for S and P five hundred futures.
CME Group's main operations are in the United States, where it operates a vertically integrated futures trading and clearing model.
As contracts entered into at CME's exchanges can't be closed at another exchange, the company's trading volume liquidity pool and market impact advantage is maintained.
The large open interest and diverse asset classes in CME's clearinghouse also provide diversification collateral benefits for its customers that would be difficult for competitors to duplicate.
When looking at CME's ability to generate excess economic returns from its moat, we focus on its adjusted returns on invested capital excluding acquisitionrelated intangibles.

We calculate the company having adjusted returns on invested capital of over twenty percent during the last five years and project adjusted returns on invested capital to grow to around forty percent over the next five years.
This compares with unadjusted returns on invested capital in the single digits.

The low unadjusted returns on invested capital caused by arguably overpaying for past acquisitions don't detract from our assessment that CME Group has a sustainable competitive advantage inherent in its business model.
Valuation three/twenty one/two thousand sixteen We are decreasing our fair value estimate for CME Group to dollar eighty nine per share from dollar ninety three.
Our fair value estimate corresponds to a price/forward earnings ratio of nineteen times and an enterprise value/EBITDA ratio of eleven times.
The primary reason for the decrease is from assuming a normalized revenue growth rate closer to the midsingle digits instead of the upper single digits.
The reduction in our revenue forecast was partially offset by the company's recent expense control and the accumulated earnings since our last valuation update.
We're forecasting a nearly six percent compound annual growth rate in revenue for CME Group over the next five years.

We're projecting strong doubledigit growth in revenue and operating income for the company in two thousand sixteen followed by midsingledigit growth in two thousand seventeen, as we believe economic uncertainties won't clear up within one year.

However, we're forecasting two thousand eighteen to be a revenue and earnings downward reset year, as the markets have a better idea of what more normalized economic growth and the supply and demand for commodities will occur.
For the company's average rate per contract, we model it being roughly flat.
In CME Group's nontransaction revenue lines, we're forecasting growth rates of two.five percent to four.five percent .

After a flat expense year because of costcutting initiatives, we project a normalized expense growth rate of four percent and have operating margins reaching sixty five percent by the fifth year of our explicit forecast period.
We use a nine percent cost of equity in our model.

Risk nine/twenty one/two thousand fifteen The largest threat to CME Group's business model and value is also the largest threat to its moat: a separation or opening up of the vertically integrated clearing house.
CME : CME Group Inc Class A Analyst Report | Analyst Report
That said, we don't believe regulators are likely to revisit this issue until larger areas of concern in the financial sector and economy are addressed.
Even if the arrangement between CME Group's exchange and clearinghouse were changed, CME Group's network effect, cost advantage, and exclusive licenses would continue to be strong moat sources.
A prolonged economic malaise would arguably be worse for CME Group than an uncertain economic environment or a recession.
If commodity prices and interest rates were to stay lower for longer and the market coalesces around that view, then there would be less speculative trading and hedging activity.

Because of the high operating leverage in CME Group's business model and the difficulty of determining the compounded effect of macroeconomic factors, technology, global expansion initiative, and regulation on trading volumes, we assign a high uncertainty rating to our valuation.
Management three/twenty one/two thousand sixteen We view CME Group's stewardship of shareholder capital as Standard.
The company's board splits the roles of chairman and CEO, an arrangement we generally favor.
CME's leadership has extensive experience in the futures business, so we view the company as being in good hands, from a strategic viewpoint.
The company's executive chairmanalso its presidentis Terrence Duffy, who has been on the board since one thousand nine hundred ninety five and is a former trading executive.
The CEO is Phupinder Gill, formerly CME Group's president and a company veteran of more than twenty years.
We think Duffy and Gill have the needed experience and skills to operate the company.
CME has grown its dividend over the years and it instituted a special annual variable dividend.

We view these as positive steps to return capital to investors indeed, we think the special dividend deserves special praise as a show of the company's commitment to consistently deliver excess cash to shareholders.

However, while management has generally increased CME Group's top and bottom lines over the years, we are not overly pleased with the returns the company has posted as measured by return on invested capital, including the impact of goodwill and other intangibles.
Much of this is due to the additional invested capital the company is carrying as a result of its big acquisitions.
While the deals certainly were important strategically, their returns have been questionable thus far, in our view.
Overview Profile: Based in Chicago, CME Group operates four U.S. financial exchanges.
The company's roots stretch back to the nineteenth century it became a shareholderowned corporation in two thousand and went public in two thousand two.

CME Group's exchanges specialize in derivatives productssuch as futures and options on futurestied to sectors such as interest rates, equity indexes, foreign exchange, energy, agricultural commodities, metals, weather, and real estate.

Investment Thesis one/seven/two thousand sixteen Not all fast casual restaurant concepts are created equal.

With a simple but uniquely customizable menu featuring naturally raised and organic products and aesthetically pleasing restaurant designs, Chipotle has cultivated a powerful brand intangible asset, the basis for our narrow moat rating.
This has helped drive industry leading comparable sales and restaurant level margins during the past several years in a tepid environment for most rivals.
Additionally, by sourcing from local ranchers and farmers, Chipotle has gained more clout with suppliers than chains of comparable size.

Although near term sales trends will be pressured by ongoing E. coli and other food safety investigations, we are optimistic that Chipotle's competitive position will remain intact longer term, indicating a runway of excess economic returns.

With dollar four.five billion in sales during two thousand fifteen, Chipotle is the dominant player in the dollar nine billion plus domestic fastcasual Mexican category and one of the largest players in the dollar forty billion plus domestic fast casual industry.

We expect Chipotle and other fast casual restaurants which offer higher quality ingredients than quick service chains but at lower average prices than casual dining restaurants to collectively grow nine percent the next five years, given compelling consumer value propositions and strong unit economics .
This exceeds our low single digit growth forecast for the broader restaurant industry.

If Chipotle can match the density of its more mature markets, we estimate that it could approach to four thousand domestic units before nearing saturation, implying high single digit unit growth for at least a decade.

We find Chipotle's secondary concepts and international plans intriguing possibly extending the ultimate store base to five thousand six thousand units but it will take years before these initiatives have a cash flow impact.
In our view, Chipotle is poised to capitalize on several productivity efforts, with online ordering/payments, catering, delivery, and daypart expansion offering longer term top line benefits.
Economic Moat one/seven/two thousand sixteen Nonexistent switching costs, intense industry rivalry, and low barriers to entry make it difficult for restaurant operators to establish an economic moat.

However, with industry leading comparable sales growth during the past several years and restaurant level margins during an increasingly competitive environment for restaurant operators, we believe Chipotle has carved out a narrow economic moat.
Breaking down Chipotle's recent comparable restaurant sales trends, we see many characteristics that validate the strength of its brand intangible asset.
From two thousand ten to two thousand fourteen, Chipotle averaged ten percent comparablerestaurant sales growth, driven in large part by traffic growth.

restaurant category averages which we estimate in the low single digit range across all restaurant categories and low to mid single digit growth for fast casual concepts implying market share gains and putting the strength of Chipotle's brand intangible asset in perspective.
However, we believe Chipotle's transaction growth during the latter part of this five year period is particularly noteworthy, as it has remained positive despite menu price increases.
In our view, this validates the pricing power inherent in the brand, a key component when evaluating intangible assets among restaurant and retail companies.
Chipotle's success and compelling unit economics have not gone unnoticed, spawning multiple fast casual restaurant rivals with aggressive growth aspirations.

We anticipate that category rivalry will escalate and evolve over the next several years, forcing firms to increasingly compete with one another for share through new menu innovations, aggressive pricing, and limited time offers .

Additionally, with retail landlords looking for tenants for unoccupied real estate and restaurant operators finding themselves with easier access to capital, we anticipate that new fast casual restaurant entrants will increasingly come to the market.
However, we believe Chipotle has separated itself from its fast casual peers and can defend market share from new rivals while maintaining pricing power.

This is in large part due to its Food with Integrity mantra, upscale restaurant environments, and distinctively customizable menu structure, each of which enriches Chipotle's brand intangible asset moat source.
While the impact of the recent E. coli investigation and other food safety concerns at Chipotle restaurants has been severe, we also plan to maintain our narrow moat rating.

We believe Chipotle's brand intangible asset is strong enough to withstand these incidents, and as the public becomes aware of new food safety protocols at its suppliers and its restaurants, we fully anticipate a recovery in restaurant traffic.

That said, we acknowledge there are downside risks to our moat rating if the Department of Justice investigation into food safety practices exposes additional issues, or if new E. Coli or norovirus situations arise in the months to come.
We also like the company's strategy of doing just a few things, but doing them very well.
Chipotle's basic menu structure reduces employee training costs but remains customizable.

Because its restaurants use an assembly line for food preparation, they can accommodate heavier restaurant traffic volume than casualdining chains, and recent efforts to improve throughput during peak hours have been effective.
Restaurant designs combine simple building materials with contemporary architecture styles, keeping up front capital requirements relatively low and creating an inviting atmosphere.
By sourcing naturally raised and organic products often from local ranchers and farmers Chipotle has more clout with its suppliers than chains of comparable size.
The company also has developed a strong culture by promoting from within, which we believe has led to betteroperated restaurants and reduced turnover.
economics and more than enough free cash flow to support growth initiatives.
Our model forecasts that ROIC should improve to the low thirtys as the firm expands its footprint over the next ten years, adding support for our narrow moat rating.

Nevertheless, we harbor concerns about new fast casual restaurant entrants attempting to replicate Chipotle's assembly line food preparation, restaurant design, real estate, and streamlined menu strategies.
These concerns prevent us from assigning the company a wide economic moat or a cost advantage moat source.

Valuation three/sixteen/two thousand sixteen We're trimming our fair value estimate to dollar five hundred twenty five per share from dollar five hundred fifty to account for the increased margin pressures, including the implementation of new food safety protocols, increased labor staffing, elevated marketing and promotional efforts, and legal expenses tied to the ongoing Department of Justice investigation.

Our fair value estimate implies fiscal two thousand eighteen price/earnings of twenty five times, enterprise value/EBITDA of twelve times, and a free cash flow yield of three percent, each of which exceeds industry averages; this is appropriate, given Chipotle's narrow moat rating and longer term cash flow prospects.

Based on the precipitous drop in comps to start the year comparable sales fell thirty six percent during January two thousand sixteen and twenty six percent in February two thousand sixteen and negative publicity tied to the expanded nationwide scope of a previously announced criminal investigation into food safety issues, we expect fullyear two thousand sixteen comps to decline in the low teens range.
We expect high twenty percent declines in comparable sales during the first quarter, with gradual improvement throughout the year .

While the first quarter will likely represent the low point for same store sales and profitability assuming no new food safety developments, and assuming that the Department of Justice investigation is resolved in two thousand sixteen we now believe midteens restaurant margins, mid single digit operating margins, and EPS of around dollar four.fifty are realistic estimates for two thousand sixteen .

Assuming the company is successful with food safety awareness and other promotional measures, we anticipate that two thousand seventeen will be a recovery year, with comps in the low double digit range and low to midteen comp growth and restaurant margins in the low to mid twentys range.
Between two thousand eighteen and two thousand twenty, we forecast midteens average annual revenue growth, including low double digit unit growth and mid single digit comps .

While we're tempering our near term estimates, our five year margin assumptions restaurant margins in the mid to high twentys and high teen operating margins still place Chipotle in the upper echelon of nonfranchised restaurant chains and provide long term investors with a compelling investment story.
Risk one/seven/two thousand sixteen In our view, Chipotle's most significant risk is increased competition on several fronts.

Many quick service chains are upgrading their menus, in restaurant experience, decor, and digital engagement efforts, while many casual dining firms have become more focused on enhancing their value proposition.

with retail landlords looking for tenants for unoccupied real estate and restaurant operators finding themselves with easier access to capital, we believe new fast casual restaurant concepts will increasingly come to the market over the near future while smaller chains will continue to pursue aggressive growth plans.
This includes an emergent group of more upscale fast casual players that could target Chipotle's affluent and millennial audiences.
If its brand appeal isn't as wide as we believe, Chipotle could face market saturation sooner than anticipated.
Demographic shifts, an increasing number of meals prepared at home, and ongoing consumerspending headwinds could dampen top line results.
Food, labor, energy, and occupancy cost volatility as well as negative publicity tied to foodborne illness or other quality concerns could disrupt results .
Chipotle's international expansion and secondary concepts, including ShopHouse Southeast Asian Kitchen and Pizzeria Locale, carry their own set of execution risks.
Management three/sixteen/two thousand sixteen Chipotle boasts a seasoned management team with a great deal of restaurant industry expertise.
Chairman and co CEO Steve Ells, who holds a degree from the Culinary Institute of America, founded Chipotle in one thousand nine hundred ninety three.
President and co CEO Montgomery Moran formally joined the firm in early two thousand five, but had long served as Chipotle's general counsel.
CFO Jack Hartung, a two decade veteran of McDonald's, has been with Chipotle since two thousand two.
Ells beneficially owns about one percent of the total equity while Moran owns around one.four percent, providing enough of an incentive to increase shareholder value, in our view.
Although we'd prefer the roles of chairman and co CEO to be split and the board to declassify, we have not witnessed any abuses of power under this corporate governance structure.
Chipotle has historically been a strong allocator of capital, with the majority of free cash flow used to fund growth initiatives, namely high return restaurant openings.
Management has also been opportunistic with share repurchases, buying back more than four.two million shares for dollar seven hundred million since two thousand eight.
However, given the lofty price at which some recent shares have been bought back, we'd prefer that capital also be returned to investors in the form of a dividend.
Overview Profile: Chipotle Mexican Grill is the largest player in the dollar nine billion plus domestic fast casual Mexican restaurant category.
Its menu includes burritos, bowls, tacos, and salads, which are made from higher quality ingredients than at quick service restaurants.
Because customers can choose from four different meats, two types of beans, and an array of extras, more than sixty five thousand menu combinations are possible.
December two thousand fifteen, the firm operated more than two thousand restaurants in forty five states, Canada, the United Kingdom, France, and Germany.

Investment Thesis // Compass Minerals holds an enviable portfolio of costadvantaged assets.
Its rock salt mine in Ontario benefits from unique geology and with access to a deepwater port can deliver deicing salt to customers at low cost.
Additionally, the company controls one of only three naturally occurring brine sources that produces sulfate of potash, or SOP, a specialty fertilizer priced at a premium to standard potash.
These operations at the Great Salt Lake in Utah can produce SOP at a significantly lower cost than producers using a chemical process.
About percent of Compass' salt sales are to highway deicing customers.

Salt is the most economical method to clear snowy and icy roadways during winter, and with mines close to waterways like the Great Lakes and Mississippi River, Compass can competitively deliver deicing salt to local governments and municipalities.
Salt's low value/weight ratio makes location very important to a company's cost structure.
Pricing for deicing salt has been historically stable, especially compared with prices for other commodities.
Prices are determined annually by a governmentdirected bid process, in which prices are set during the summer for the following winter season.
A snowy winter generally leads to higher prices in the following summer bid season.
Sales volume is determined during the winter months and is strongly linked to the number of snow days per season.
As such, weather has a big impact on Compass' yearto year results, and salt volume fluctuates considerably.
Compass is also a costadvantaged producer of its other main product, sulfate of potash, which is a specialty fertilizer used by growers of highvalue crops that are sensitive to standard potash .
While marginal producers of SOP use MOP and sulfuric acid to produce SOP, Compass makes SOP directly from salt brines at a considerably lower cost.
SOP prices generally track MOP prices, but a widerthannormal gap has opened up between the two more recently, with SOP prices remaining elevated despite a drop in MOP prices.
We expect this spread to tighten, leading to slimmer perton profits for the company's fertilizer business.
Economic Moat // We think Compass possesses a wide economic moat.
It holds unique assets that are difficult, if not impossible, to replicate, giving the firm a sustainable cost advantage over other producers of salt and sulfate of potash.
The company's rock salt mine in Goderich, Ontario, is the world's largest active salt mine.
At Goderich, Compass mines deposits that are feet thick many competing mines have seams that are only about feet thick.
This allows Compass to use more efficient mining techniques and remove more salt for
Investment Thesis eight/ seventeen/two thousand fifteen With a proven constructive framework for utility regulation in Michigan, CMS is on steady footing despite its heavy parent debt load.
This regulatory support gives it a foundation on which it can grow earnings faster than peers during the next five years, fueled by a substantially higher investment program.
We forecast seven percent earnings growth from two thousand fifteen twenty, driving a similar level of dividend growth.
CMS' growth plans include upgrades to its electric and gas distribution infrastructure, system reliability improvements, and environmental controls for its coal heavy fleet.
We expect regulatory support for these projects given Michigan's energy needs due to the retirement of aging coal plants.
However, we think longterm energy demand growth in the state will be sluggish, a headwind to CMS's long term earnings growth.
CMS and peer DTE Energy should benefit from the federal Clean Power Plan if it is implemented.
This could offset the weak economic fundamentals given significant needs for new gas and renewable generation.
Michigan's regulatory environment has made great progress since the two thousand eight energy legislation passed.
While most provisions have stuck, the courts struck down an electric decoupling mechanism that helped smooth earnings.
Regardless, a string of generally positive rate cases suggests that the regulatory atmosphere in Michigan has improved.
If CMS can keep rate increases at or near its targets, the prospect of regulatory pushback will be less daunting.
However, a weak economy always makes it more difficult to pass through higher rates.
Utilities in the state continue to enjoy a favorable political climate.
Another round of legislation further attacks the state's past efforts to open up energy supply competition, forcing more load back into CMS' system.
This might provide opportunities for higher future investment to meet the captive load.
We think CMS' regulated utilities are in good shape, but the parent carries far too much debt, and investors should consider the extra refinancing risk if credit markets tighten.

Economic Moat eight/ seventeen/two thousand fifteen Service territory monopolies and efficient scale advantages are the primary moat sources for regulated utilities like C Miss State and federal regulators grant CMS exclusive rights to charge customers rates that allow it to earn a fair return on and return of the capital it invests to build, operate, and maintain its generation, transmission, and distribution electricity and gas networks.
In exchange for its service territory monopoly, regulators set returns at levels that aim to minimize customer costs while offering fair returns for capital providers.
We project CMS will earn a small but consistent spread over its cost of capital for the foreseeable future.
CMS' regulated utilities have realized a string of fairly constructive rate outcomes.

The overall environment has become more utility friendly with the Republican takeover of the House and Senate and the appointment of a former investment analyst to the Chairmanship of the Michigan Public Service Commission.
The more constructive regulatory environment is driving CMS to invest heavily at its regulated electric utility.
Michigan is among the states that will need the most investment in gas and renewable generation if the federal Clean Power Plan is implemented.
This likely gives CMS' investments both regulatory and possible legislative backing to ensure stable earned returns on new investments.

Alternatives that wouldn't contribute to higher investment or earnings like signing PPAs with local merchant gas plants aren't available in Michigan after the utilities snapped up the remaining plants in the region.

Valuation two/ seventeen/two thousand sixteen We're increasing our fair value estimate for CMS to dollar thirty three per share from dollar thirty per share after incorporating full year two thousand fifteen results, increasing our regulated capital expenditure forecast and incorporating modestly better rate case outcomes for the gas and electric utilities.

Risk eight/ seventeen/two thousand fifteen The biggest threat to CMS' future earnings ability is capricious state regulation.
Regulators may choose to disallow recovery of CMS' investments in rates or place political expedience above the interests of CMS' investors by maintaining or lowering rates.
Given the state of Michigan's economy, that risk is greater than for some other utilities peers.
We think rate self implementation poses a danger to the utilities politically in the long run, as regulators and ratepayers tire of clawing back increases.
The primary driver behind CMS' earnings growth and value creation is regulated capital investment, and the degree to which the company can recover its costs with an appealing return.
CMS has much higher refinancing risk than most of its regulated peers given the sizable debt load at the parent.
Management eight/ seventeen/two thousand fifteen We give CMS' management team a Standard stewardship rating.
CEO John Russell led Consumers Energy for nearly a decade before assuming the leadership role at CMS from former CEO David Joos in two thousand ten.
As former head of the utilities business, we think Russell has been a good fit for CMS's move toward growing the regulated businesses, picking up on Joos' back to basics strategy.
Russell has stuck with the program and overseen a period of improved regulatory relations and consistent utility performance.
Management has consistently pushed to improve regulatory mechanisms we consider investor friendly, with fairly good success.
We give current management significant credit for adapting to a new regulatory playing field without pursuing rate increases too aggressively.
We consider leverage at the parent company to be much too high, and we believe debt reduction should be a higher priority.
Overview Profile: CMS Energy is an energy holding company with two principal segments, Consumers Energy, and Enterprises.
Consumers provides regulated natural gas and electric service to roughly six.five million customers in Michigan.
Enterprises is engaged in wholesale power generation in various locations in the United States.

Investment Thesis eleven/twenty/two thousand fifteen CenterPoint's regulated utilities have significant investment opportunities even though sustained low natural gas and oil prices have lowered our expectations for earnings and cash distributions from Enable Midstream Partners LP.

We expect Houston Electric and CenterPoint's six natural gas distribution utilities to increase their rate bases approximately five.five percent annually during the next five years, due in large part to above average electricity demand growth in Houston and reliability infrastructure improvements to the gas distribution utilities that include operations in Minneapolis and Houston.

With improved Texas regulation and higher capital expenditures, we estimate that Houston Electric will increase transmission and distribution operating income by approximately six percent annually during the next five years.
This is based on our rate base growth assumption and regulatory frameworks that for the most part are constructive for shareholders.
The strong rate base growth is primarily due to above average electricity demand growth in Houston and reliability infrastructure improvements.

We estimate annual operating income growth at the natural gas distribution segment during the next five years will average about eight percent, driven by rate base growth due in large part to upgrading gas transmission and distribution piping for safety.
The main infrastructure project is the dollar four hundred million Minnesota Belt Line Project, which will likely take another fifteen years to complete.
In two thousand thirteen, CenterPoint formed Enable with two other firms, contributing all of its interstate pipelines and field services business.
